content: One of the most controversial issues in U.S. foreign assistance is the debate over restrictions on funding for abortion and family planning activities abroad. The key questions revolve around whether recipients of U.S. assistance perform abortions or engage in coercive practices with U.S. funds, and whether funding should be withheld from such entities. The impact of withholding funds on population growth, family planning, and reproductive health services in developing countries is also a point of contention among members of Congress. Members of Congress have debated the impact of withholding U.S. funds on population growth, family planning, and reproductive health services in developing countries, in connection with U.S. abortion policy controversies since Roe v. Wade. Legislation prohibiting abortion has been introduced in nearly every Congress. The Constitution protects a woman's right to choose abortion. Congressional opponents have introduced legislation to ban abortion and restrict federal funding for the procedure. The debate has expanded to include U.S. foreign assistance. The debate in Congress over federal funding of abortion has expanded to include U.S. foreign assistance. The "Mexico City policy," implemented by President Reagan in 1984, required foreign NGOs receiving USAID family planning assistance to certify they would not promote abortion. This policy has been rescinded and reinstated by various Administrations, most recently by President Trump in 2017. The USAID issued Policy Determination 3 (PD-3) on voluntary sterilization (VS) in September 1982 to ensure that funded services protect individuals' needs and rights.
